pullRequest.title: Refactor Server Http2 Implementation
pullRequest.bodyText: Remove NettyMessageProcessor and reuse client handlers.

nodes.bodyText: ctx.writeAndFlush would do the work. By the way, maybe we can do ctx.isOpen check before we write, it, the connection might be closed before server got a chance to write.
what happened to connetionstats handler, why we drop it here.
I would go against using writeAndFlush here, this is a write method, it should just call ctx.write and let the caller do writeAndFlush.

This metric seems to just record the time it takes to call requestQueue.put, which should be short unless the queue is full. Is that intended? Is there another metric to record the time the request spends in the queue?
release dup if an exception occurs?
add javadoc for what forServer changes.

A caller calling writeAndFlush here will likely result in a call to AbstractChannelHandlerContext.writeAndFlush which calls invokeWriteAndFlush. This appears to call flush, but feeds the promise only to the write call (invokeWrite0). I'm pretty sure the promise is only completed once the message is actually flushed though.
So, I feel that the difference between just calling write here vs calling writeAndFlush would be that flush would be called twice in a row if the caller already calls writeAndFlush.
Does closing this channel end just this stream or trigger a connection close? I would also like to learn more about when GOAWAY frames are sent.
Where is the CONTENT_LENGTH header set now since it's being removed from here?

as per my understanding the functional difference between write and writeAndFlush is that writeAndFlush writes the data immediately to the socket buffer whereas with write() the flushing to socket buffer does not happen untill a certain number of buffer is accumulated at netty layer which is controlled through setWriteBufferHighWaterMark in ChannelConfig i think. Usually writeAndFlush() is needed for latency sensitive protocols, it may a bit costly if lots of small messages are being sent out using writeAndFlush.
